description: Understand the fundamental principles of User Interface (UI) and User Experience (UX) design.

slides.title: What is UI vs UX?
slides.content:
# UI vs UX ðŸŽ¨

**UI (User Interface):** The visual look of the product. Colors, fonts, buttons, images.

**UX (User Experience):** How the product feels and works. Flow, usability, accessibility, and user satisfaction.

> "UX is how it works, UI is how it looks."

slides.title: The Design Process
slides.content:
# Design Thinking ðŸ§ 

A 5-stage process:

1.  **Empathize:** Understand user needs.
2.  **Define:** State the problem.
3.  **Ideate:** Brainstorm solutions.
4.  **Prototype:** Build rough drafts.
5.  **Test:** Validate with users.

slides.title: User Research
slides.content:
# User Research ðŸ•µï¸â€â™€ï¸

Gathering data to understand user behaviors needed and pain points.

Methods:
- **Surveys:** Broad data collection.
- **Interviews:** Deep qualitative insights.
- **Personas:** Fictional characters representing user types.
- **User Journeys:** Mapping the steps a user takes to achieve a goal.

slides.title: Wireframing
slides.content:
# Wireframing ðŸ“

A low-fidelity visual guide that represents the skeletal framework of a website or app.

- Focuses on layout and structure, not colors or images.
- Like a blueprint for a house.
- Tools used: Pen & Paper, Balsamiq, Figma.

slides.title: Concept Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which term refers to the 'skeletal framework' of an app?

slides.title: Prototyping
slides.content:
# Prototyping ðŸ“±

A simulation of the final interaction.

- **Low-Fidelity:** Clickable wireframes.
- **High-Fidelity:** Looks and feels like the real app.
- Purpose: To test the flow and usability before writing code.

slides.title: Visual Hierarchy
slides.content:
# Visual Hierarchy ðŸ‘ï¸

Arranging elements to show their order of importance.

Achieved through:
- **Size:** Bigger is more important.
- **Color:** Bright colors draw attention.
- **Contrast:** Stand out from background.
- **Whitespace:** Separation indicates grouping.

slides.title: Typography in UI
slides.content:
# Typography Rules ðŸ…°ï¸

- **Readability:** Text must be legible.
- **Hierarchy:** Use H1, H2, Body text sizes distinctly.
- **Font Pairing:** Use 1-2 font families max.
- **Line Height:** Ensure enough breathing room (1.5x is standard).

slides.title: Color Theory
slides.content:
# Color Theory ðŸŒˆ

Colors evoke emotions and guide actions.

- **Primary:** Brand identity.
- **Secondary:** Accents.
- **Neutral:** Backgrounds and text.
- **Semantic:** Red (Error), Green (Success), Yellow (Warning).

Rule of thumb: **60-30-10 rule** (60% dominant, 30% secondary, 10% accent).

slides.title: Accessibility (A11y)
slides.content:
# Accessibility â™¿

Designing for ALL users, including those with disabilities.

- **Contrast:** Text must stand out from background.
- **Alt Text:** For screen readers.
- **Keyboard Nav:** Product usable without a mouse.
- **Focus States:** Clearly visible active elements.

slides.title: Color Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: According to the 60-30-10 rule, what percentage should be the accent color?

slides.title: Usability Testing
slides.content:
# Usability Testing ðŸ§ª

Observing users trying to complete tasks with your product.

- **Moderated:** Guided by a researcher.
- **Unmoderated:** User completes tasks alone while recording screen/voice.
- **A/B Testing:** Comparing two versions to see which performs better.

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: UI/UX ðŸŽ“

Design with purpose.

- **UX:** Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype, Test.
- **UI:** Visuals, Typography, Color, Spacing.
- **Artifacts:** Wireframes -> Mockups -> Prototypes.
- **Goal:** Solve user problems effectively and delightfully.
